en.sc1: Let's look at an example to see the difference between shallow and deep copying.
en.sc2: First let's create an <tt>Employee</tt> object with name field 'Sam'. This is referenced by <tt>firstEmployee</tt>.
en.sc3: Then let's 'shallow copy' by creating a new reference named <tt>shallowCopyEmployee</tt>, and making it also reference the same <tt>Employee</tt> object that <tt>firstEmployee</tt> references.
en.sc4: Now, using setName(), update the Employee object's name as "John", which shallowCopyEmployee is pointing to.
en.sc5: If you print out the name of firstEmployee, you will see that the name of the Employee is now "John," not "Sam.".
en.sc6: Now, let's create another <tt>Employee</tt> object, referneced by <tt>secondEmployee</tt>. Set the name of this employee to be 'Patrice'.
en.sc7: Then we create a third <tt>Employee</tt> object, referenced by <tt>deepCopyEmployee</tt>.
en.sc8: After that, copy the name of the object referenced by <tt>secondEmployee</tt> and set that name into the object referenced by <tt>deepCopyEmployee</tt>. So you deep-copied the contents of <tt>secondEmployee</tt>'s object.
en.sc9: Now, let's set the name of the object referenced by <tt>deepCopyEmployee</tt> to 'John'.
en.sc10: Finally, if you print the name of <tt>secondEmployee</tt>, it is still 'Patrice'. Changing <tt>deepCopyEmployee</tt>'s name did not affect <tt>secondEmployee</tt>'s name.
